title: Women at heart of rise in activity levels over past year as Sport England praises Telegraph revolution in coverage
text:
Netball, cycling, weights and interval training are among the activities which have driven a surge of a quarter of a million more women to become active over the past year.

In announcing figures which also showed record adult levels since its surveys started in 2015, Sport England also specifically praised The Telegraph’s revolution this year in its coverage of women’s sport.

The number of women who are classified as active has risen by 254,200 over the past 12 months but, crucially, there are also 142,000 fewer women at the opposite end of the scale who are now considered inactive and doing less than 30 minutes of activity every week.

Record overall activity levels among adults since 2015 has been underpinned by more women taking part in sport and, as well as the impact of Sport England’s This Girl Can initiative, the role of the media was particularly highlighted.

The Telegraph launched its Girls, Inspired campaign to close the gender gap in school sport in April and has also transformed the scope and depth of its coverage of women’s sport from the grass roots all the way up to the very elite.

“There is visibility and a positive energy around women’s sport,” said Lisa O’Keefe, the insight director at Sport England. “This visibility doesn’t just extend to elite athletes and events – it goes much broader than that. The work you [The Telegraph] are doing in terms of really putting women and girls front and centre is so important in terms of sending messages that sport is an OK place to be, and that women will be encouraged and welcomed. There’s an attitude shift among women themselves and also the people delivering sport.”
